abstract.shortdesc: Adding a VSA node allows you to add additional capacity.
abstract.p: You may have a need to add a VSA node for additional storage capacity or another purpose and these steps will help you achieve this.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: You should have one or more baremetal servers that meet the minimum hardware requirements for a VSA node which are documented in the Hardware Support Matrix.

section.title: Adding a VSA Node
section.p: These steps will show you how to add the new VSA node to your servers.yml file and then run the playbooks that update your cloud configuration. You will run these playbooks from the lifecycle manager.

ol.li: Log in to your lifecycle manager.
Checkout the site branch of your local git so you can begin to make the necessary edits: cd ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data git checkout site

In the same directory, edit your servers.yml file to include the details about your new VSA node(s).
For example, if you already had a cluster of three VSA nodes and needed to add a fourth one you would add your details to the bottom of the file in this format: # VSA Storage Nodes
- id: vsa4 ip-addr: 10.13.111.148 role: VSA-ROLE server-group: RACK1 nic-mapping: HP-DL360-4PORT mac-addr: f0:92:1c:05:f5:78 ilo-ip: 192.168.9.4 ilo-password: password ilo-user: admin
You can find detailed descriptions of these fields here. You will need to verify that the ip-addr value you choose for this node does not conflict with any other IP address in your cloud environment. You can confirm this by checking the ~/helion/my_cloud/info/address_info.yml file on your lifecycle manager.

In your control_plane.yml file you will need to check the values for member-count, min-count, and max-count, if you specified them, to ensure that they match up with your new total node count. So for example, if you had previously specified member-count: 3 and are adding a fourth VSA node, you will need to change that value to member-count: 4.
See Input Model - Control Plane for more details.
Commit the changes to git: git commit -a -m "Add node <name>"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the ready deployment playbook: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Add the new node into Cobbler: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml

Then you can image the node: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=<node name> If you don't know the <node name> already, you can get it by using sudo cobbler system list
Before proceeding, you may want to take a look at ~/helion/my_cloud/info/server_info.yml to see if the assignment of the node you have added is what you expect. It may not be, as nodes will not be numbered consecutively if any have previously been removed. This is to prevent loss of data; the config processor retains data about removed nodes and keeps their ID numbers from being reallocated. See the Persisted Server Allocations section in Input Model for information on how this works.
Run the following command: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-run.yml

Run this command to complete the deployment of your new node, ensuring you use the --limit option to specify your new node: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-deploy.yml --limit <host_var name> If you don't know the <host_var name> already, you can get it by looking in the ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible/host_vars directory.

section.title: Adding a New VSA Node to your CMC Management Cluster
section.p: You can add VSA nodes to an existing cluster using either the CMC utility or an Ansible playbook.
If you created the VSA cluster using Ansible, you can add nodes to that cluster using the same playbook. Perform the following steps:

ol.li: Edit your servers.yml file to include the details about your new VSA node(s), as described previously.
Run the following command from your first controller node: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts vsalm-configure-cluster.yml
When prompted, enter an administrative user name and password you will use to administer the CMC utility.

On your lifecycle manager, collect the IP addresses of the VSA virtual machines that you added from the ~/scratch/ansible/next/my_cloud/stage/info/net_info.yml file. This file is generated as part of output of the configuration processor during installation. You will need this IP address in the next steps.
Launch the CMC utility. You will likely want to use the same method you used when you did your initial VSA cluster configuration. See Launching the CMC utility GUI for more details.
In the CMC GUI, click the Find menu and then select the Find Systems options.

Click the Add button which will open the Enter IP Address dialogue box where you can enter the IP address of the VSA node(s) that you are adding. These will be the same IP addresses you noted in step 1 from your ~/scratch/ansible/next/my_cloud/stage/info/net_info.yml file.
Once you have all of your VSA nodes entered, click the Close button.
Next, click the Tasks menu and then navigate to the System submenu and select the Add to Existing Management Group option.
In the Management Group wizard, select your new VSA node and then press Continue.
Select your Group Name from the drop down box and then press Add to continue.
The CMC utility will then add your new VSA node to the management group. Once it has completed you will see the Status change to Storage System Normal.

Add the VSA node to an existing cluster.
Right click the newly added VSA node and select Add to Existing Cluster:
Select your cluster from the drop down box. Select the storage system to add to the cluster and then click OK:
You can then mouse over your VSA node to see the Storage System get successfully added to the cluster:
You can then continue on to create additional volumes.
